section: The Seven Years' War in India
text: During the years 1759 and 1760, Frederick the Great of Prussia continued his struggle against larger powers.  This diverted France's attention from England, allowing the British to focus on colonial expeditions.  In India, the recall of Dupleix had placed the British and French East India Companies on equal footing, but the Marquis de Bussy, a supporter of Dupleix's expansionist policies, remained in the Deccan.  In 1756, following the Black Hole of Calcutta, Robert Clive recaptured the city.  Subsequent conflicts with the Nabob of Bengal and the French at Chandernagore culminated in the Battle of Plassey in 1757, marking the beginning of British dominance in India.  Clive, adopting Dupleix's strategies, secured Bengal for the British.  Control of the sea was crucial for European powers in India, allowing small forces to maintain control amidst larger native populations, provided they weren't opposed by other European powers.

section: Naval Battles in the East Indies
text: While Clive operated in Bengal, Bussy advanced French interests elsewhere in India. A French squadron arrived in 1758, challenging British naval supremacy.  The first naval battle, off the Coromandel Coast in April 1758, was indecisive, but prevented the British from relieving Fort St. David, which subsequently fell to the French. A second battle in August was similarly inconclusive, but revealed the critical weakness of the French position: a lack of supplies and repair facilities.  Forced to retreat to the Isle of France, the French squadron found the colony equally depleted.  The situation highlighted the chronic underfunding and poor logistics that plagued the French navy.  Despite repairs and a return to India in September 1759, D'Ache, the French commander, was again defeated by the British admiral Pocock and retreated, leaving the French position in India increasingly precarious.

section: The Fall of French Power in India
text: D'Ache's departure marked a turning point.  Without naval support, Lally's land campaign faltered. The British, receiving consistent reinforcements, captured French holdings one by one.  In January 1761, Pondicherry, the last French stronghold, surrendered.  Despite later regaining some possessions in peace treaties, French power in India was effectively broken.  The contrast between D'Ache and the later French admiral Suffren is striking. Suffren, facing similar logistical challenges two decades later, displayed the vigor and leadership that D'Ache lacked.  Spain's decision to enter the war alongside the clearly weakened France seems ill-advised, given the vulnerability of Spain's own overseas empire.

section: The Decline of French Naval Power and the Bourbon Family Compact
text: French naval historians extensively document the exhaustion of French resources by 1761.  Few single ships left port, and all were captured. The alliance with Spain came too late to save France’s remaining colonies. As early as 1758, France, lacking funds, ships, and supplies, resorted to avoiding direct naval engagements. The arrival of a mere four ships-of-the-line at Louisburg was considered a fortunate event, highlighting the precarious state of their navy.  The destruction of French commerce, starting with merchant ships, culminated in the loss of colonies. The Family Compact between France and Spain, including a secret clause obliging Spain to declare war on England within a year if peace wasn't achieved, was unwise. Spain entered a disadvantageous agreement, hoping to revive the French navy and forge an alliance of neutral powers who had grievances against England.  English cruisers often disrespected the Spanish flag, seizing neutral vessels carrying goods from French colonies or military stores. This fueled resentment and contributed to the later “armed neutrality” of Baltic powers against England's maritime claims.  England's unchallenged sea power led to disregard for others' rights, asserting the right to seize enemy property on neutral ships. This disrupted trade and caused losses for neutral nations, similar to England's earlier paper blockade of French ports. Although neutrals were frustrated, 1761 was not the time for armed protest, especially for Spain. England possessed a formidable navy of 120 ships-of-the-line, manned by 70,000 experienced sailors.  In contrast, the French navy, once numbering 77 ships-of-the-line, had suffered heavy losses. Spain's navy of 50 ships likely had inferior personnel.  Neutrality, despite occasional violations, had benefited Spain, allowing it to recover financially and rebuild resources, but more time was needed.  Influenced by family ties and resentment, the Spanish king was persuaded by Choiseul to sign the Family Compact on August 15, 1761. This pact, also intended for Naples, guaranteed mutual possessions.  A secret clause stipulated Spain's declaration of war against England by May 1, 1762, if peace with France hadn't been achieved.

section: England's Preemptive War and Swift Victories
text: Pitt learned of Spain’s impending hostility and sought to preemptively declare war, but was overruled and resigned on October 5, 1761. His foresight was proven correct. Spain stalled, awaiting treasure ships from America. These arrived safely in Cadiz on September 21st, followed by richly laden ships from the West Indies on November 2nd.  Spain's tone shifted dramatically, asserting grievances and claims against England. The new English ministry, despite desiring peace, recalled their ambassador and declared war on January 4, 1762, effectively adopting Pitt’s strategy, but too late for the element of surprise.  England's superior strength and preparation remained unchanged.  Pocock, back from the East Indies, sailed from Portsmouth on March 5th, escorting transports to attack Havana. He was reinforced in the West Indies, commanding nineteen ships-of-the-line and 10,000 soldiers.  In January, Rodney's West India fleet and land forces captured Martinique, a key French island and privateering hub.  This disrupted privateering operations and secured English colonies and trade. Martinique's fall was followed by the capture of Grenada, St. Lucia, and St. Vincent, making all the Lesser Antilles British possessions.  Pocock's fleet, reinforced, navigated the Old Bahama Channel to Havana, a challenging feat at the time, arriving without incident. The siege of Havana lasted forty days, culminating in the capture of Moro Castle on July 30th and the city on August 10th. Spain lost the city, port, twelve ships-of-the-line, and substantial wealth. Havana’s importance stemmed not only from its size and rich surrounding area, but also its control over the passage for treasure ships from the Gulf of Mexico to Europe. Its capture forced ships to assemble in Cartagena and sail against trade winds, increasing their vulnerability. This blow to Spain was facilitated by England’s sea power, which also enabled the timely transport of American troops to reinforce the depleted English forces.  While England's sea power dominated the West Indies, it was also instrumental in Portugal and the East Indies.  Portugal, pressured by the allied crowns to join their alliance against the “tyrants of the seas,” resisted despite the threat to its neutrality.  The allies invaded Portugal but England responded, sending a fleet and troops to Lisbon, repelling the Spaniards and even carrying the war into Spain.

section: Capture of Manila and the End of the War
text: Unable to spare resources from England, the capture of Manila was undertaken by officials in India. The expedition sailed in August 1762, resupplied at neutral Malacca (with Dutch acquiescence), and successfully captured the Philippine Islands in October, securing a substantial ransom. Simultaneously, the fleet seized the Acapulco galleon and its riches, while another squadron captured a treasure ship from Lima.  These events severely crippled Spain’s colonial empire, disrupting trade and communication.  Pitt's strategy of targeting key points effectively severed Spain's strength. While the element of surprise was lost, the rapid execution of plans, enabled by England's efficient navy, led to triumph. With Manila's fall, the war's military operations concluded.  In just nine months, France’s hopes were dashed and Spain was forced into a peace conceding all points that had triggered the conflict.  England's naval dominance played a decisive role in the war's outcome.

section: The Impact of Sea Power on England's Success and Prosperity
text: The speed and thoroughness of England's wartime achievements were primarily attributed to her sea power. This enabled her forces to operate across vast distances, from Cuba and Portugal to India and the Philippines, without fear of communication disruptions.  The magnitude of England's merchant ship losses paradoxically demonstrated her prosperity: despite significant captures by French privateers, the sheer size of the English merchant fleet, estimated at eight thousand ships, absorbed these losses. French privateering itself stemmed from the decline of their own merchant fleet, forcing idle sailors and owners into piracy. While privateers did inflict losses on English commerce, especially in coastal trade, the overall balance favored England. Key victories like the capture of Duquesne, Louisburg, and Prince Edward's Island, alongside the reduction of Senegal, Guadeloupe, and Martinique, severely hampered French commerce and colonies while bolstering England's.  The vast difference in prisoners of war further highlighted England's dominance: England held twenty-five thousand French prisoners, while only twelve hundred Englishmen were held in France. The influx of captured Spanish specie, combined with bills of exchange paid in British manufactures, fueled trade and industry. This sustained economic prosperity, even amidst a costly war, was unprecedented and showcased England's strength.

section: England's Strategic Alliances and the Peace of Paris
text: England's alliance with Portugal, though seemingly unequal, provided crucial naval bases and access to resources, especially valuable in conflicts with southern European powers. Portugal, caught between England and Spain, ultimately chose to maintain the alliance with England, recognizing the greater immediate threat. The Peace of Paris in 1763 redrew the map of global power. France ceded Canada, Nova Scotia, and territories east of the Mississippi (excluding New Orleans) to England. Spain, in exchange for the return of Havana, ceded Florida.  This expanded England's colonial empire significantly across North America.  In the West Indies, some islands were exchanged, with England retaining strategically important territories.  Minorca returned to English control, and France ceded Louisiana west of the Mississippi to Spain. In India, France regained pre-war possessions but lost political influence, effectively ceding control to the English East India Company. Fishing rights in Newfoundland and the Gulf of St. Lawrence were granted to France but denied to Spain. Public opinion in England, including prominent figures like Pitt, criticized the treaty's leniency, particularly the return of French colonies and Indian trading posts. These concessions allowed France to potentially rebuild its navy and commerce, challenging England’s maritime dominance. The restoration of Havana was also deemed insufficiently compensated by the acquisition of Florida. Despite these criticisms, England’s territorial gains, naval supremacy, and enhanced global prestige solidified its position as a major power.

section: Influence of Sea Power in Remote and Disordered Countries
text: The terms of the peace after the Seven Years' War were simply the status quo ante helium.  To attribute the outcome solely to differences between land and sea war is absurd. Frederick's genius, backed by English money, matched the coalition.  States with good seaboards or ocean access benefit from seeking prosperity and extension through sea commerce rather than unsettling existing political arrangements in countries where long possession has conferred rights and created national allegiance. Since the 1763 Treaty of Paris, the world's waste places have been filled (North America, Australia, South America).  Nominal political possession often exists even in forsaken regions, but in many places, it's feeble and can't support itself. The Turkish Empire, kept erect by opposing forces and mutual jealousies, exemplifies weak political tenure; sea powers' interest and control are chief elements fixing the situation and directing future changes. The unstable political condition of Central and South American states causes anxiety about internal order and interferes with commerce and resource development.  As long as they 'hurt no one but themselves,' this can continue, but citizens of stable governments seeking to exploit their resources have borne losses from their distracted condition. As North American and Australian opportunities diminish, demand will arise for more settled governments in disordered states, ensuring security and institutional stability for merchants.  No present hope exists that this demand can be fulfilled with existing native materials; when it arises, no theoretical positions (like the Monroe Doctrine) will prevent interested nations from interfering politically. Such interference can cause collisions, sometimes settled by arbitration, but also war.  Even for peaceful solutions, the nation with the strongest organized force will have the strongest arguments. Piercing the Central American Isthmus could precipitate the inevitable moment of intervention.  Modified commercial routes and the political importance of such a channel for the US are not the whole question.  The time will come when stable governments for American tropical states must be assured by powerful American or European states.  Sea power will determine which foreign state predominates – if not by possession, by influence. The US has an undeniable advantage due to geography and power, but this won't avail if there's a great inferiority of organized force. The Seven Years' War holds living interest.  England, with a small army, defended her shores, carried arms in every direction, spread rule and influence, and bound remote regions to her, making them tributary to her wealth, strength, and reputation. As she loosened France and Spain's grasp in overseas regions, there's perhaps a prophecy of some future nation inclining the balance of power in a future sea war, whose scope will be the political future and economic development of regions previously lost to civilization; but not the US if she remains indifferent to the empire of the seas.

England's efforts, directed by national instinct and Pitt's genius, continued after the war and profoundly influenced her subsequent policy. Mistress of North America, lording over twenty million inhabitants in India through the company whose conquests native princes ratified – a population larger than Great Britain's with respectable revenue – England had before her the lesson of Spain's weakness. The words of an English naval historian about Spain apply to England today: "Spain is precisely that power against which England can always contend with...advantage and honor. That extensive monarchy is exhausted at heart, her resources lie at a great distance, and whatever power commands the sea, may command the wealth and commerce of Spain. The dominions from which she draws her resources, lying at an immense distance from the capital and from one another, make it more necessary for her than for any other State to temporize, until she can inspire with activity all parts of her enormous but disjointed empire." Though untrue to say England is exhausted, her dependence on the outside world gives the phrase suggestiveness.  England hasn't overlooked this analogy.  Her sea power and the possessions it won have controlled her policy. The road to India – once a perilous voyage without English stopping-places – was reinforced by acquiring St. Helena, the Cape of Good Hope, and Mauritius.  When steam made the Red Sea route practicable, she acquired Aden and later Socotra.  Malta, acquired during the French Revolution, was claimed in 1815.  A thousand miles from Gibraltar, their military commands intersect.  The stretch from Malta to Suez is now guarded by Cyprus.  Egypt, despite French jealousy, is under English control.  Its importance to India, understood by Napoleon and Nelson, led the latter to send news of the Nile victory overland to Bombay. England's jealousy of Russia's Central Asian advance results from when her sea power wrenched India from French ambition. M. Martin, speaking of the Seven Years' War, said, "For the first time since the Middle Ages, England had conquered France single-handed almost without allies, France having powerful auxiliaries. She had conquered solely by the superiority of her government." Yes, but by her government using sea power.  This made her rich and protected her trade.  With her money, she upheld Prussia and Hanover. Her power reached wherever her ships could, undisputed at sea.  Her mobility multiplied her forces and distracted enemies'.  Ruling the seas, she obstructed highways. Enemy fleets couldn't join; none could escape, or if so, only to meet veteran English crews. Except Minorca, she held her bases and seized the enemy's. Gibraltar blocked French squadrons; Louisburg aided the English fleet against Canada. The nation that gained used the sea for peacetime wealth and ruled it in war through naval extent, seafaring subjects, and numerous bases.  These bases lose value with obstructed communications. Hence, the French lost Louisburg, Martinique, Pondicherry; England lost Minorca. Service between bases and mobile forces is mutual. The navy is a light corps; it keeps its communications open, obstructs the enemy's, sweeps the sea for the land, and controls the desert so man can thrive.

section: Choiseul's Naval Focus and Spanish Alliance
text: The virtual annihilation of the French fleet in 1759 spurred national enthusiasm for naval restoration, skillfully guided by Choiseul.  Cities, corporations, and individuals contributed funds, leading to a surge of activity in French ports.  Choiseul also aimed to restore naval discipline and morale.  However, initiating these preparations mid-war proved too late.  Spain, in a better initial position with an estimated sixty ships-of-the-line, joined France against England. Despite this alliance, England's superior numbers, skill, experience, and prestige proved overwhelming. After the war, Choiseul continued naval restoration, fostering professional ambition among officers.  Shipbuilding flourished, resulting in forty ships-of-the-line by war's end and sixty-four ships-of-the-line and fifty frigates by 1770. Arsenals were stocked, and a timber reserve established.  Choiseul also addressed the aristocratic arrogance among naval officers, which undermined subordination.  A sense of social equality among officers, regardless of rank, hindered effective command.  This contrasted sharply with the ingrained meritocratic system of the British navy.  Insubordination plagued the French fleet, hindering even the capable Suffren. Choiseul's reforms struggled against this ingrained social hierarchy, ultimately remedied only by the revolution. Crew personnel, however, saw significant improvements, including the formation and training of a ten-thousand-strong gunner corps.  Simultaneously, Choiseul cultivated the Spanish alliance, encouraging Spain's progress under Charles III. While maintaining the Austrian alliance, he prioritized Spain due to its proximity, naval position, and shared animosity towards England over Gibraltar, Minorca, and Florida.

section: Missed Opportunities and Shifting Power Dynamics
text: France's growing naval power caused concern in England, but internal issues and the brewing American colonial conflict restrained English action.  Two opportunities for conflict arose.  First, in 1764, Genoa effectively ceded Corsica to France.  Despite English protests, only a single voice in Parliament advocated war over this strategically important island.  Second, in 1770, a dispute over the Falkland Islands erupted. Spain, with a superior force, seized the English settlement at Port Egmont. This act, unlike the Corsican transfer, sparked outrage in England, prompting naval mobilization.  Spain, anticipating French support, initially resisted English demands. However, Louis XV's aversion to war and Choiseul's dismissal led to Spanish compliance, though the sovereignty issue remained unresolved.  These events demonstrated England's naval strength but also its reluctance to engage in war solely to counter rival naval development.  The first partition of Poland in 1772, facilitated by Choiseul's focus on naval policy and the Spanish alliance, further weakened France's traditional continental influence.  Louis XV's death in 1774, coinciding with escalating American colonial tensions, ushered in Louis XVI, who continued the policies of continental peace, Spanish alliance, and naval expansion. This foreign policy, inherited from Choiseul, targeted England's sea power as the primary threat and emphasized French sea power as the nation's principal defense. The instructions given to Louis XVI's ministers reflected this strategic vision: vigilance against threats, naval monitoring of key areas, observation of English military and economic conditions, covert support for American colonists, and continued, discreet naval development in preparation for potential conflict with England, coordinated with Spanish naval preparations.

section: Character of the Naval War of 1778
text: assemble numerous troops upon the shores of Brittany and Normandy, and get everything ready for an invasion of England, so as to force her to concentrate her forces, and thus restrict her means of resistance at the extremities of the empire. Such instructions, whether given all at once as a symmetrical, well-thought-out plan, or from time to time, as occasion arose, showed that an accurate forecast of the situation had been made, and breathed a conviction which, if earlier felt, would have greatly modified the history of the two countries. The execution was less thorough than the conception. In the matter of developing the navy, however, fifteen years of peace and steady work showed good results. When war openly broke out in 1778, France had eighty ships-of-the-line in good condition, and sixty-seven thousand seamen were borne on the rolls of the maritime conscription. Spain, when she entered the war in 1779 as the ally of France, had in her ports nearly sixty ships-of-the-line. To this combination England opposed a total number of two hundred and twenty-eight ships of all classes, of which about one hundred and fifty were of the line. The apparent equality in material which would result from these numbers was affected, to the disadvantage of England, by the superior size and artillery of the French and Spaniards; but on the other hand her strength was increased by the unity of aim imparted by belonging to one nation. The allies were destined to feel the proverbial weakness of naval coalitions, as well as the degenerate administration of Spain, and the lack of habit — may it not even be said without injustice, of aptitude for the sea — of both nations. The naval policy with which Louis XVI. began his reign was kept up to the end; in 1791, two years after the assembly of the States-General, the French navy numbered eighty-six ships-of-the-line, generally superior, both in dimensions and model, to English ships of the same class. We have come, therefore, to the beginning of a truly maritime war; which, as will be granted by those who have followed this narrative, had not been seen since the days of De Ruyter and Tourville. The magnificence of sea power and its value had perhaps been more clearly shown by the uncontrolled sway, and consequent exaltation, of one belligerent; but the lesson thus given, if more striking, is less vividly interesting than the spectacle of that sea power meeting a foe worthy of its steel, and excited to exertion by a strife which endangered, not only its most valuable colonies, but even its own shores. Waged, from the extended character of the British Empire, in all quarters of the world at once, the attention of the student is called now to the East Indies and now to the West; now to the shores of the United States and thence to those of England; from New York and Chesapeake Bay to Gibraltar and Minorca, to the Cape Verde Islands, the Cape of Good Hope, and Ceylon. Fleets now meet fleets of equal size, and the general chase and the melee, which marked the actions of Hawke, Boscawen, and Anson, though they still occur at times, are for the most part succeeded by wary and complicated manoeuvres, too often barren of decisive results as naval battles, which are the prevailing characteristic of this coming war. The superior tactical science of the French succeeded in imparting to this conflict that peculiar feature of their naval policy, which subordinated the control of the sea by the destruction of the enemy's fleets, of his organized naval forces, to the success of particular operations, the retention of particular points, the carrying out of particular ulterior strategic ends.

text: It is not necessary to endeavor to force upon others the conviction of the present writer that such a policy, however applicable as an exception, is faulty as a rule; but it is most desirable that all persons responsible for the conduct of naval affairs should recognize that the two lines of policy, in direct contradiction to each other, do exist. In the one there is a strict analogy to a war of posts; while in the other the objective is that force whose destruction leaves the posts unsupported and therefore sure to fall in due time. These opposing policies being recognized, consideration should also be had of the results of the two as exemplified in the history of England and France. It was not, however, with such cautious views that the new king at first sought to impress his admirals. In the instructions addressed to the Count d'Orvilliers, commanding the first fleet sent out from Brest, the minister, speaking in the name of the king, says: — "Your duty now is to restore to the French flag the lustre with which it once shone; past misfortunes and faults must be buried out of sight; only by the most illustrious actions can the navy hope to succeed in doing this. His Majesty has the right to expect the greatest efforts from his officers. . . . Under whatever circumstances the king's fleet may be placed, his Majesty's orders, which he expressly charges me to impress upon you, as well as upon all officers in command, are that his ships attack with the greatest vigor, and defend themselves, on all occasions, to the last extremity." More follows to the same effect; upon which a French officer, who has not before been quoted in connection with this phase of French naval policy, says: — "How different this language from that held to our admirals during the last war; for it would be an error to believe that they followed by choice and temper the timid and defensive system which predominated in the tactics of the navy. The government, always finding the expenses exacted by the employment of the navy excessive, too often prescribed to its admirals to keep the sea as long as possible without coming to pitched battles, or even to brushes, generally very expensive, and from which might follow the loss of ships difficult to replace. Often they were enjoined, if driven to accept action, carefully to avoid compromising the fate of their squadron by too decisive encounters. They thought themselves, therefore, obliged to retreat as soon as an engagement took too serious a turn. Thus they acquired the unhappy habit of voluntarily yielding the field of battle as soon as an enemy, even inferior, boldly disputed it with them. Thus to send a fleet to meet the enemy, only to retire shamefully from his presence; to receive action instead of offering it; to begin battles only to end them with the semblance of defeat; to ruin moral force in order to save physical force, — that was the spirit which, as has been very judiciously said by M. Charles Dupin, guided the French ministry of that epoch. The results are known." The brave words of Louis XVI. were followed almost immediately by others, of different and qualifying tenor, to Admiral d'Orvilliers before he sailed. He was informed that the king, having learned the strength of the English fleet, relied upon his prudence as to the conduct to be followed at a moment when he had under his orders all the naval force of which France could dispose. As a matter of fact the two fleets were nearly equal; it would be impossible to decide which was the stronger, without detailed information as to the armament of every ship. D'Orvilliers found himself, as many a responsible man has before, with two sets of orders, on one or the other of which he was sure to be impaled, if unlucky; while the government, in the same event, was sure of a scape-goat.

meta.use_case: Examination of French naval orders and their impact on naval strategy

text: The consideration of the relative force of the two navies, material and moral, has necessarily carried us beyond the date of the opening of the American Revolutionary War. Before beginning with that struggle, it may be well to supplement the rough estimate of England's total naval force, given, in lack of more precise information, by the statement of the First Lord of the Admiralty made in the House of Lords in November, 1777, a very few months before the war with France began. Replying to a complaint of the opposition as to the smallness of the Channel fleet, he said: — “We have now forty-two ships-of-the-line in commission in Great Britain (without counting those on foreign service), thirty-five of which are completely manned, and ready for sea at a moment's warning. . . . I do not believe that either France or Spain entertains any hostile disposition toward us; but from what I have now submitted to you, I am authorized to affirm that our navy is more than a match for that of the whole House of Bourbon.” It must, however, be said that this pleasing prospect was not realized by Admiral Keppel when appointed to command in the following March, and looking at his fleet with (to use his own apt expression) “a seaman's eye;” and in June he went to sea with only twenty ships. It is plainly undesirable to insert in a narrative of this character any account of the political questions which led to the separation of the United States from the British Empire. It has already been remarked that the separation followed upon a succession of blunders by the English ministry, — not unnatural in view of the ideas generally prevalent at that day as to the relations of colonies to the mother-country. It needed a man of commanding genius to recognize, not only the substantial justice of the American claims, — many did that, — but also the military strength of their situation, as before indicated. This lay in the distance of the colonies from home, their nearness to each other independently of the command of the sea, the character of the colonists, — mainly of English and Dutch stock, — and the probable hostility of France and Spain. Unfortunately for England, the men most able to cope with the situation were in the minority and out of office. It has been said before that, had the thirteen colonies been islands, the sea power of Great Britain would have so completely isolated them that their fall, one after the other, must have ensued. To this it may be added that the narrowness of the strip then occupied by civilized man, and the manner in which it was intersected by estuaries of the sea and navigable rivers, practically reduced to the condition of islands, so far as mutual support went, great sections of the insurgent country, which were not large enough to stand alone, yet too large for their fall not to have been a fatal blow to the common cause. The most familiar case is that of the line of the Hudson, where the Bay of New York was held from the first by the British, who also took the city in September, 1776, two months after the Declaration of Independence. The difficulties in the way of moving up and down such a stream were doubtless much greater to sailing vessels than they now are to steamers; yet it seems impossible to doubt that active and capable men wielding the great sea power of England could so have held that river and Lake Champlain with ships-of-war at intervals and accompanying galleys as to have supported a sufficient army moving between the head-waters of the Hudson and the lake, while themselves preventing any intercourse by water between New England and the States west of the river. This operation would have closely resembled that by which in the Civil War the United States fleets and armies gradually cut in twain the Southern Confederacy by mastering the course of the Mississippi, and the political results would have been even more important than the military; for at that early stage of the war the spirit of independence was far more general and bitter in the section that would have been cut off, — in New England, — than in New York and New Jersey, perhaps than anywhere except in South Carolina.

meta.use_case: Analysis of British strategic failures in the American Revolutionary War

section: Part 1: The North American Theater and Maritime Conflict
text: The British forces' corps were positioned out of mutual support, abandoning control of the Hudson River's water-line. While Burgoyne advanced with seven thousand regular troops and auxiliaries to seize the river's headwaters, fourteen thousand men were shifted from its mouth to the Chesapeake.  The remaining eight thousand near New York were tied to the city due to the American army's presence in New Jersey. This disastrous August maneuver led to Burgoyne's isolated surrender in October. The following May, the British evacuated Philadelphia, enduring a difficult retreat through New Jersey with Washington in pursuit, finally reaching New York.  Moving the British fleet to the Chesapeake's head, along with the 1814 Potomac ascent by English frigates, exposed another weak point in the American colonies. Unlike the Hudson-Champlain line, vulnerable at both ends to enemy control (Canada and the sea), this weakness was less critical. Regarding the broader sea warfare, the colonists, unable to confront the British fleet, relinquished sea control. They resorted to privateering, exploiting their maritime skills to disrupt English commerce. By 1778's end, American privateers had captured nearly a thousand merchant ships, valued at almost £2,000,000, although English historians claim heavier American losses.  This was plausible, given the superior support and power of British cruisers, while the growth of American commerce had astonished British statesmen. At war's outbreak, it rivaled England's own commerce at the century's beginning. The First Lord of the Admiralty highlighted North America's seafaring population, stating the navy's loss of eighteen thousand seamen from the last war due to "not having America"—a significant loss to any sea power, especially when these seamen potentially joined the enemy. Sea warfare predictably led to neutral grievances against English seizures of ships trading with America. However, such provocation wasn't needed to fuel French animosity and ambitions, given Britain's strained government. Choiseul's vengeful policy seemed near fruition.  Paris debated its stance and how to exploit the colonial revolt. They decided on maximum support short of open conflict with England. Beaumarchais, a Frenchman, received funds to establish a firm supplying war materials to the colonists. France and Spain each contributed a million francs, and Beaumarchais accessed government arsenals. Simultaneously, agents from the United States were received, and French officers joined American service with minimal government interference. Beaumarchais's operation began in 1776.  December saw Franklin's arrival in France, and Lafayette reached America in May 1777. War preparations, particularly naval, intensified; the French navy grew, and plans for a Channel invasion were made, while the colonies were the intended war theatre.  France had little to lose. Stripped of Canada, she believed war renewal, with a neutral Europe and friendly Americans, wouldn't cost her Caribbean islands. Acknowledging American opposition to Canada's return, France disavowed such aims while stipulating retention of any seized English West Indian possessions.  Spain's situation differed. Despising England, desiring Gibraltar, Minorca, and Jamaica's return (keystones of her sea power), she recognized the danger of successful English colonial rebellion as an example to her own vast colonial system, which provided substantial annual subsidies. If England's navy failed, what could Spain achieve?

section: Part 2: Spanish Dilemma, Treaty, and Military Overview
text: In the introductory chapter, the inherent contradiction in Spain’s position was highlighted: its revenue came not from a diversified, robust maritime economy but a fragile trickle of colonial wealth.  Spain had much to lose and potentially gain.  It remained the ideal adversary for England, but grievances and dynastic sympathies prevailed, leading Spain down the same covert hostile path as France. Burgoyne's surrender ignited this volatile situation. France, aware of American strength from past conflicts and expecting their assistance, now feared an independent America might reject alliances. The news reached Europe on December 2, 1777; by December 16, France offered recognition of American independence, a commercial treaty, and a contingent defensive alliance.  The rapid progress demonstrated France’s readiness, and the momentous treaty was signed on February 6, 1778.  Key aspects include France's renunciation of Canada and Nova Scotia (foreshadowing the Monroe Doctrine's principles, requiring naval strength for enforcement) and the alliance providing the Americans with a crucial counterbalance to British sea power. American pride notwithstanding, without French naval opposition, Britain could likely have subdued the Atlantic seaboard.  It’s vital to acknowledge the crucial role France played in American victory.  Before examining the maritime war, a review of the global military situation is needed. Three key differences distinguish it from the 1756 Seven Years’ War: America’s hostility towards England, Spain’s early alliance with France, and the other continental powers’ neutrality, freeing France from land-based distractions.  In North America, the Americans held Boston for two years. The British occupied Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island, New York, and Philadelphia.  Chesapeake Bay, lacking strong fortifications, was vulnerable to any hostile fleet.  The South remained largely inactive since the failed 1776 Charleston attack; the war’s main events before France’s declaration were north of the Chesapeake. Conversely, the American campaign in Canada had failed, providing a secure base for British power.  In Europe, French and (to a lesser degree) Spanish naval preparedness contrasted sharply with previous wars.  England, isolated and defensive, faced the Bourbon monarchs' ambitions to conquer Gibraltar and Port Mahon and invade England. The first two were Spain's priorities, the last France’s, creating a divergence of aims that ultimately undermined the maritime coalition.  The introductory chapter touched upon the strategic issues arising from these conflicting objectives.

section: Part 3: West Indies, India, and Interconnected Theaters of War
text: In the West Indies, both sides held roughly equal ground, although this shouldn’t have been the case. France and England had strong positions in the Windward Islands—Martinique and Barbados, respectively. Barbados's windward location provided a significant strategic advantage in the age of sail. Fighting was largely concentrated around the Lesser Antilles.  Dominica, an English island situated between the French Martinique and Guadeloupe, was a desirable target and was subsequently seized. South of Martinique lay St. Lucia, a French colony.  Its sheltered harbor, Gros Islet Bay, offered an excellent vantage point for observing the French navy at Fort Royal, Martinique. The English captured the island, and Rodney used this secure anchorage to monitor and pursue the French fleet before his famous 1782 victory. The islands further south were of lesser military importance. Spain, controlling Cuba, Puerto Rico, and (jointly with France) Hispaniola, should have outweighed England, who held only Jamaica.  However, Spain’s contribution was negligible, and England was too preoccupied elsewhere to attack her. Spanish forces made their presence felt only in Florida (then an English possession), which didn’t join the colonial rebellion. In the East Indies, France had regained its trading posts in the 1763 peace, but unlike the British dominance in Bengal, France lacked comparable control in any part of the peninsula.  The English expanded their power in the following years, aided by capable leaders like Clive and Warren Hastings.  However, powerful native adversaries emerged in the south, presenting an ideal opportunity for France to regain influence when war erupted. Yet, the French government and people remained oblivious to the region's potential. England, however, recognized the opportunity.  The same day news of the war reached Calcutta (July 7, 1778), Hastings ordered an attack on Pondicherry and set the example by seizing Chandernagore. Naval forces on both sides were minimal, but the French commodore abandoned Pondicherry after a brief engagement, leading to its surrender after a seventy-day siege.  In March 1779, Mahé, the last French settlement, fell, and the French flag disappeared again. Simultaneously, a strong English squadron of six ships-of-the-line under Admiral Hughes arrived.  The lack of a comparable French force gave England complete sea control until Suffren's arrival nearly three years later. Meanwhile, Holland entered the war, and its stations—Negapatam on the Coromandel coast and the crucial Trincomalee harbor in Ceylon—were captured, the latter in January 1782 by joint army-navy operations. These successes solidified the military situation in India just before Suffren's arrival a month later transformed the nominal war into a fierce and bloody struggle. Suffren commanded a stronger squadron but lacked a friendly port to base operations against the English. Of the four main theaters—North America, West Indies, Europe, and India—the first two, due to proximity, were intertwined and directly influenced each other.  This was less apparent for the conflicts in Europe and India. The narrative therefore naturally divides into three main sections, which can be examined individually before considering their interplay and any valuable lessons.

section: Outbreak of War and Battle of Ushant
text: On March 10, 1778, France formally recognized the United States and entered into a treaty with them, prompting England to recall its ambassador.  Despite England's disadvantageous position, Spain offered mediation, causing France to delay its attack.  In June, Admiral Keppel sailed from Portsmouth and initiated hostilities with French frigates, learning of a larger French fleet in Brest. After reinforcing, Keppel engaged D'Orvilliers's fleet west of Ushant on July 27, 1778. This indecisive battle, involving thirty ships-of-the-line on each side, resulted in no ships lost or captured.  The battle's lack of a clear victor fueled public and political controversy in England, with accusations exchanged between Keppel and another officer.  Tactically, the battle is notable for Keppel's attempt to force an action from a leeward position by ordering a general chase to windward, a move that eventually allowed the fleets to engage.  D'Orvilliers, initially unwilling to fight except on his own terms, responded to Keppel's maneuvers. The fleets exchanged ineffective broadsides while passing on opposite tacks. A potentially advantageous maneuver by the French van, commanded by the Duc de Chartres, was not executed, raising questions about the ideal position of a commander-in-chief during battle.

meta.use_case: Analysis of a historical naval battle

section: Position of an Admiral in Battle
text: The Battle of Ushant highlighted the ongoing debate about the optimal position for a naval commander-in-chief.  D'Orvilliers's inability to directly control the French van led to a missed opportunity.  Various positions were considered: the center of the line offered equal visibility (or lack thereof) of the fleet's extremities; leading from the van provided direct leadership by example; and a position outside the line of battle, on a frigate, allowed for a clearer overview of the battle and better signal visibility, similar to a general's position on land.  The frigate position, adopted by Howe and the French, was later abandoned. Nelson, at Trafalgar, led from the front, but this may have been driven by his personal fighting spirit rather than tactical advantage.  The traditional practice was for the admiral to be in the center of the line. Nelson and Collingwood's leading of their columns at Trafalgar, while successful, exposed them to significant risk.  The loss of these key figures could have severely impacted the battle.  Their rapid disappearance into the smoke also limited their ongoing command and control.  The attack formation at Trafalgar, with two columns approaching a perpendicular line, sacrificed the leading ships to create breaches, into which fresher ships could then advance, effectively acting as a reserve.  This raises the question of whether the admiral should be positioned with this reserve to maintain control and influence later in the battle.

meta.use_case: Discussion of command principles in naval warfare

text: Farragut's practice, particularly later in his career after New Orleans and Vicksburg, was to lead from the front. At Mobile, he reluctantly agreed to take the second position and later regretted doing so. However, Farragut's battles differed from traditional fleet engagements. His objectives were to pass fortifications, not engage in prolonged battles, often under challenging pilotage conditions where he possessed superior knowledge of the terrain. This necessitated his leadership at the front, both literally and figuratively. By leading, he guided the fleet through safe passages, maintained visibility ahead of the smoke, and assumed responsibility for the chosen course, a responsibility a subordinate might hesitate to take. Notably, at Mobile, leaders of both columns questioned Farragut's intentions at a critical juncture, not due to unclear orders, but because the circumstances appeared different from what he had anticipated. This emphasizes the importance of the commander's direct presence and control in complex and dynamic situations.

section: Position of a Naval Commander-in-Chief in Battle
text: Tecumseh," departed from the admiral's orders and left the course dictated to them, with disastrous results. There is no necessity to condemn either captain; but the irresistible inference is that Farragut was unqualifiedly right in his opinion that the man who alone has the highest responsibility should, under the conditions of his battles, be in the front. And here it must be remarked that at such critical moments of doubt any but the highest order of mind tends to throw off the responsibility of decision upon the superior, though from the instancy of the case hesitation or delay may be fatal. A man who as the commissioned chief would act intelligently, as the mere subordinate will balk. Nelson's action at St. Vincent will rarely be emulated, a truth which is strongly shown by the fact that Collingwood was immediately in his rear that day, and did not imitate his action till signaled by the commander-in-chief; yet after receiving the authority of the signal, he particularly distinguished himself by his judgment and daring. It will be recalled, also, in connection with this question of pilot-ground battles, that a central position nearly lost the flag-ship at New Orleans, owing to the darkness and to the smoke from the preceding ships; the United States fleet came near finding itself without its leader after the passage of the forts. Now as the mention of a reserve prompted one set of considerations, so the name of pilotage suggests certain ideas, broader than itself, which modify what has been said of keeping the admiral with the reserve. The ease and quickness with which a steam fleet can change its formation make it very probable that a fleet bearing down to attack may find itself, almost at the very moment of collision, threatened with some unlooked-for combination; then where would be the happiest position for an admiral? Doubtless in that part of his own order where he could most readily pilot his ships into the new disposition, or direction, by which he would meet the changed conditions; that is, in the position of leading. It would seem that there are always two moments of greatest importance in a sea-fight; one which determines the method of the main attack, the other the bringing up and directing the effort of the reserve. If the first is more important, the second perhaps requires the higher order of ability; for the former may and should proceed on a before-determined plan, while the latter may, and often must, be shaped to meet unforeseen exigencies. The conditions of sea-battles of the future contain one element that land battles cannot have, — the extreme rapidity with which encounters and changes of order can take place. However troops may be moved by steam to the field of battle, they will there fight on foot or on horseback, and with a gradual development of their plan, which will allow the commander-in-chief time to make his wishes known (as a rule, of course), in case of a change in the enemy's attack. On the other hand, a fleet, comparatively small in numbers and with its component units clearly defined, may be meditating an important change of which no sign can appear until it begins, and which will occupy but a few minutes. So far as these remarks are sound, they show the need of a second in command thoroughly conversant with not only the plans, but with the leading principles of action of his chief, — a need plain enough from the fact that the two extremities of the order-of-battle may be necessarily remote, and that you want the spirit of the leader at both extremities. As he cannot be there in person, the best thing is to have an efficient second at one end.

As regards Nelson's position at Trafalgar, mentioned at the beginning of this discussion, it is to be noted that the "Victory" did nothing that another ship could not have done as well, and that the lightness of the wind forbade the expectation of any sudden change in the enemy's order. The enormous risk run by the person of the admiral, on whose ship was concentrated the fire of the enemy's line, and which led several captains to implore a change, was condemned long before by Nelson himself in one of his letters after the battle of the Nile: — "I think, if it had pleased God I had not been wounded, not a boat would have escaped to have told the tale; but do not believe that any individual in the fleet is to blame. ... I only mean to say that if my experience could in person have directed those individuals, there was every appearance that Almighty God would have continued to bless my endeavors," etc. Yet, notwithstanding such an expression of opinion based upon experience, he took the most exposed position at Trafalgar, and upon the loss of the leader there followed a curious exemplification of its effects. Collingwood at once, rightly or wrongly, avoidably or unavoidably, reversed Nelson's plans, urged with his last breath. "Anchor! Hardy, do you anchor!" said the dying chief. "Anchor!" said Collingwood. "It is the last thing I should have thought of."

section: Maritime War in North America and West Indies, 1778-1781
text: On the 15th of April, 1778, Admiral Comte d'Estaing sailed from Toulon for the American continent, having under his command twelve ships-of-the-line and five frigates. With him went as a passenger a minister accredited to Congress, who was instructed to decline all requests for subsidies, and to avoid explicit engagements relative to the conquest of Canada and other British possessions. "The Cabinet of Versailles," says a French historian, "was not sorry for the United States to have near them a cause of anxiety, which would make them feel the value of the French alliance." While acknowledging the generous sympathy of many Frenchmen for their struggle, Americans need not blind themselves to the self-interestedness of the French government. Neither should they find fault; for its duty was to consider French interests first. D'Estaing's progress was very slow. It is said that he wasted much time in drills, and even uselessly. However that may be, he did not reach his destination, the Capes of the Delaware, until the 8th of July, — making a passage of twelve weeks, four of which were spent in reaching the Atlantic. The English government had news of his intended sailing; and in fact, as soon as they recalled their ambassador at Paris, orders were sent to America to evacuate Philadelphia, and concentrate upon New York. Fortunately for them, Lord Howe's movements were marked by a vigor and system other than D'Estaing's. First assembling his fleet and transports in Delaware Bay, and then hastening the embarkation of stores and supplies, he left Philadelphia as soon as the army had marched from there for New York. Time was taken up in reaching the mouth of the bay; but he sailed from it the 28th of June, ten days before D'Estaing arrived, though more than ten weeks after he had sailed. Once outside, a favoring wind took the whole fleet to Sandy Hook in two days. War is unforgiving; the prey that D'Estaing had missed by delays foiled him in his attempts upon both New York and Rhode Island. The day after Howe's arrival at Sandy Hook the English army reached the heights of Navesink, after an harassing march through New Jersey, with Washington's troops hanging upon its rear. By the active co-operation of the navy it was carried up to New York by the 5th of July; and Howe then went back to bar the entrance to the port against the French fleet. As no battle followed, the details of his arrangements will not be given; but a very full and interesting account by an officer of the fleet can be found in Eldns's "Naval Battles." Attention, however, may well be called to the combination of energy, thought, skill, and determination shown by the admiral. The problem before him was to defend a practicable pass with six sixty-four-gun ships and three of fifty, against eight of seventy-four guns or over, three sixty-fours, and one fifty, — it may be said against nearly double his own force. D'Estaing anchored outside, south of the Hook, on the 11th of July, and there remained until the 22d, engaged in sounding the bar, and with every apparent determination to enter. On the 22d a high northeast wind, coinciding with a spring tide, raised the water on the bar to thirty feet. The French fleet got under way, and worked up to windward to a point fair for crossing the bar. Then D'Estaing's heart failed him under the discouragement of the pilots; he gave up the attack and stood away to the southward.

Naval officers cannot but sympathize with the hesitation of a commander to disregard the advice of pilots, especially on a coast unknown to him; but such sympathy should not close their eyes to the highest type of character. Let any one compare the action of D'Estaing at New York with that of Nelson at Copenhagen and the Nile, or that of Farragut at Mobile and Port Hudson, and the inferiority of the Frenchman as a military leader, guided only by military considerations, is painfully apparent. New York was the very centre of the British power; its fall could not but have shortened the war. In fairness to D'Estaing, however, it must be remembered that other than military considerations had to weigh with him. The French admiral doubtless had instructions similar to those of the French minister, and he probably reasoned that France had nothing to gain by the fall of New York, which might have led to peace between America and England, and left the latter free to turn all her power against his own country. Less than that would have been enough to decide his wavering mind as to risking his fleet over the bar. Howe was more fortunate than D'Estaing, in having no divided purposes. Having escaped from Philadelphia and saved New York by his diligence, he had in store the further honor of saving Rhode Island by the like rapid movements. Scattered ships-of-war from a fleet despatched from England now began to arrive. On the 28th of July Howe was informed that the French fleet, which had disappeared to the southward, had been seen heading for Rhode Island. In four days his fleet was ready for sea, but owing to contrary winds did not reach Point Judith till the 9th of August. There he anchored, and learned that D'Estaing had run the batteries the day before and anchored between Gould and Canonicut Islands; the Seakonnet and Western passages had also been occupied by French ships, and the fleet was prepared to sustain the American army in an attack upon the British works. The arrival of Howe, although his reinforcements did not raise the English fleet to over two thirds the strength of the French, upset D'Estaing's plans. With the prevailing summer southwest breezes blowing straight into the bay, he was exposed to any attempts his adversary might make.

The Eng:lish fell back on New York. The French rallied again off the entrance of Narragansett Bay ; but D'Estaino- decided that he could not remain on account of the damage to the squadron, and accordingly sailed for Boston on the 21st of August. Rhode Island was thus left to the English, who retained it for a year longer, evacuating then for strategic reasons. Howe on his part diligently repaired his ships, and sailed again for Rhode Island when he heard of the French being there ; but meeting on the way a vessel with word of their going to Boston, he followed them to that harbor, in which they were too strongly placed to be attacked. Taking into consideration his enforced return to New York, the neces- sary repairs, and the fact that he was only four days behind the French at Boston, it may be believed that Howe showed to the end the activity which characterized the beginning of his operations. Scarcely a shot had been exchanged between the two fleets, yet the weaker had thoroughly outgeneral led the stronger. With the exception of the manoeuvres for the weather-gage after D'Estaing left Newport, which have not been preserved, and of Howe's dispositions to receive the expected attack in New York Bay, the lessons are not tactical, but strategic, and of present application. Chief among them undoubtedly stands the value of celerity and watchfulness, combined with knowl- edge of one's profession. Howe learned of his danger by advices from home three weeks after D'Estaing sailed from Toulon. He had to gather in his cruisers from the Chesa- peake and outside, get his ships-of-the-line from New York and Rhode Island, embark the supplies of an army of ten thousand men, move down the Delaware, — which unavoidably took ten days, — and round to New York again. D'Estaing was ten days behind him at the Delaware, twelve days at Sandy Hook, and only one day ahead of him in entering Newport, outside which harbor he had lain ten days before sailing in. An English narrator in the fleet, speaking of the untiring labor between June 30, when the English army reached Navesink, and the arrival of the French fleet on the 364 SUCCESS OF HOWE'S MOVEMENTS. 11th of July, says : " Lord Howe attended in person as usual, and by his presence animated the zeal and quickened the industry of officers and men." In this quality he was a marked contrast to his amiable but indolent brother, Gen- eral Howe. The same industry and watchfulness marked his remaining operations. As soon as the French ships hauled off to the southward, lookout vessels followed them, and preparations continued (notably of fireships) for pursuit. The last ship that joined from England crossed the bar at New York on the 30th of July
. On the 1st of August the fleet was ready for sea, with four fire-ships. The accident of the wind delayed his next movements; but, as has been seen, he came up only one day after the entrance of the enemy into Newport, which his inferior force could not have pre- vented. But the object of the enemy, which he could not oppose, was frustrated by his presence. D'Estaing was no sooner in Newport tiian he wished himself out. Howe's position was strategically excellent. With his weatherly position in reference to the prevailing winds, the difficulty of beating a fleet out through the narrow entrance to the harbor would expose the French ships trying it to be at- tacked in detail ; while if the wind unluckily came fair, the admiral relied upon his own skill to save his squadron.

text: D'Estaing, having repaired his ships, sailed with liis whole force for Martinique on the -Ith of November ; on the same day Commodore Hotham left New York for Barbadoes, with five sixty-four and fifty-gun ships and a convoy of five thousand troops, destined for the conquest of Sta. Lucia Island. On the way a heavy gale of wind injured the French fleet more than the English, the French flag-ship losing her main and mizzcn topmasts. The loss of these spars, and the fact that twelve unencumbered ships-of-war reached Martinique only one day before the convoy of fifty-nine English transports reached Barbadoes, a hundred miles farther on, tells badly for the professional skill which then and now is a determining feature in naval war. Admiral Barrington, commanding at Barbadoes, showed the same energy as Howe. The transports arrived on the 10th ; the troops were kept on board ; sailed on the morning of the 12th for Sta. Lucia, and anchored there at three p. m, the 13th. The same afternoon half the troops were landed, and the rest the next morning. They seized at once a better port, to which the admiral was about to move the transports when the appearance of D'Estaing prevented him. All that night of the transports were being warped inside the ships-of-war, and the latter anchored across the entrance to the bay, espe- cial care being taken to strengthen the two extremities of the line, and to prevent the enemy from passing inside the weather end, as the English ships in after years did at the battle of the Nile. The French was much more than double the Englisli fleet ; and if the latter were destroyed, the transports and troops would be trapped. D'Estaing stood down along the English order twice from north to south, cannonading at long range, but did not anchor. Abandoning then his intentions against the fleet, he moved to another bay, landed some French soldiers, and assaulted the position of the English troops. Failing here also, ho retired to Martinique ; and the French garrison, which had been driven into the interior of the island, surrendered. It seems scarcely necessary to point out the admirable dili- gence of Admiral Barrington, to which and to the skill of his dispositions he owed this valuable strategic success ; for such it was. Sta. Lucia was the island next south of Martinique, and the harbor of Gros Hot at its northern end was especially adapted to the work of watching the French depot at Fort Royal, their principal station in the West Indies. Thence Rodney pursued them before his great action in 1782. The absence of precise information causes hesitation in con- demning D'Estaing for this mortifying failure. His respon- sibility depends upon the wind, which may have been light under the land, and upon his power to anchor. The fact, however, remains that he passed twice along the enemy's line within cannon-shot, yet did not force a decisive action. His course was unfavorably criticised by the great SufTren, then one of his captains.^ The English had thus retrieved the capture of Dominica, which had been taken on the 8th of September by the French governor of the West India Islands. There being no English squadron there, no difficulty had been met. The value of Dominica to the French has been pointed out; and it is ^ See page 42G.

text: D'Estaing AT GRENADA. 367 necessary here to use the example of both Dominica and Sta. Lucia to enforce what has before been said, that the posses- sion of these smaller islands depended solely upon the naval preponderance. Upon the grasp of this principle held by any one will depend his criticism upon the next action of D'Estaing, to be immediately related. Six months of almost entire quiet followed the affair of Sta. Lucia. The English were reinforced by the fleet of Byron, who took chief command ; but the French, being joined by ten more ships-of-the-line, remained superior in numbers. About the middle of June, Byron sailed with his fleet to protect a large convoy of merchant-ships, bound for England, till they were clear of the islands. D'Estaing then sent a very small expe- dition which seized St. Vincent, June 16, 1779, without diffi- culty ; and on the 30th of June he sailed with his whole fleet to attack Grenada. Anchoring off Georgetown on the 2d of July, he landed his soldiers, and on the 4th the garrison of seven hundred men surrendered the island. Meanwhile Byron, hearing of the loss of St. Vincent and probable attack on Grenada, sailed with a large convoy of vessels carrying troops, and with twenty-one ships-of-the-line, to regain the one and relieve the other. Receiving on the way definite in- formation that the French were before Grenada, he kept on for it, rounding the northwest point of the island at day- break of July 6. His approach had been reported the day before to D'Estaing, who remained at anchor,^ fearing lest with the currents and light winds he might drop too far to leeward if he let go the bottom. When the English came in sight, the French got under way ; but the confused mass- ing of their ships prevented Byron from recognizing at once the disparity of numbers, they having twenty-five ships-of- the-line. He made signal for a general chase, and as the disorder of the French fleet forced it to form on the lee- wardmost ships, the English easily retained the advantage of the wind with which they approached. As the action began, therefore, the French were to the westward with a partly formed line, on the starboard tack, heading north, the rear in 1 D'Estaing's position at anchor is marked by the anchor iu Plate X. 368 NAVAL BATTLE OFF GRENADA.
